origination.corpname: Daughters of the American Revolution of Michigan.

did.unittitle: Daughters of the American Revolution of Michigan records 1893-2014
did.abstract: Michigan Society of the Daughter of the American Revolution; minutes of the state executive board, proceedings of the Michigan state conferences, publications, reports, and scrapbooks; also papers concerning their genealogical work, record of activities during World War I and II; historical files for individual chapters of the Michigan D.A.R.; and photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The record group was deposited by the organization (donor no. 1171) beginning in 1946. Periodic additions have been received.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Daughters of the American Revolution of Michigan records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Daughters of the American Revolution was founded in 1890 as a volunteer women's service organization dedicated to "promoting patriotism, preserving American history, and securing America's future through better education for children." The Michigan State Society of the DAR was founded in 1900. Individual local chapters of the DAR had been formed as early as 1893. In 2009, the Michigan Society had a membership of approximately 3000 women members in fifty-four local chapters. As a patriotic organization, the DAR has sought to promote and preserve family and local histories, to promote the celebration of national holidays, "to support our national defense, and to form friendships with others who share our love of God, Home, and Country."

scopecontent.p: The records of the Daughters of the American Revolution of Michigan document its organization, history, and activities. As the state society of the DAR, the organization also collected material on the activities of the various local chapters. The records have been arranged into the following series: State Executive Board Minutes; State Conference Proceedings (original and published); Reports; Various Records of DAR State Historian; Miscellaneous; Chapter Records (original materials, collected material, and membership yearbooks); Publications; Scrapbooks; Topical files; and Photographs.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: The Bentley Historical Library also has records from individual local chapters of the DAR. These chapters include Ann Gridley Chapter (Hillsdale, Mich.), Charity Cook Chapter (Homer, Mich.), Charles Meseroll Chapter (Union City, Mich.), Fort Pontchartrain-Elizabeth Cass Chapter (Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich.), Grand Blanc Chapter, John Biddle Chapter (Trenton, Mich.), Keziah Cooley Goss Chapter (Ann Arbor, Mich.), Lewis Cass Chapter (Escanaba, Mich.). Menominee Chapter, Quakertown Chapter (Farmington, Mich.), Sarah Caswell Angell Chapter (Ann Arbor, Mich.), Shiawassee Chapter (Owosso, Mich.), Stevens Thomson Mason Chapter (Ionia, Mich.), and the Ypsilanti Chapter.
